newsitem.title: NICARAGUA: Sandinista strike sputters at start in Nicaragua.
newsitem.headline: Sandinista strike sputters at start in Nicaragua.

text.p: Hundreds of pro-Sandinista protesters blocked major roads across Nicaragua on Monday in a national strike against the right-wing government, but the country appeared to be largely unscathed by the protest.

While traffic was slowed across Nicaragua, and strikes by some transport unions made finding a bus difficult, police reported no serious violent incidents, and stores and offices opened for business as usual.
"At this moment the situation is totally under control," Nicaragua's Police Chief Franco Montealegre said.

Strike leaders said the protest would continue until the government of President Arnoldo Aleman agreed to a 15-point list of demands, including actions to curb unemployment and resolve Nicaragua's property dispute. But government officials said turnout for the strike was low.

"I left my house this morning peacefully and heard nothing alarming. I've heard of no violence and I feel little tension in the air," National Assembly President Ivan Escobar Fornos, a member of Aleman's Liberal Alliance coalition, said.

In the past some major Sandinista-led street protests have led to bloody shootouts between protesters and police. The Sandinista Front, which came to power in the 1979 revolution, is now the country's main opposition party.

Fears of a violent protest were raised on Monday when local newspaper La Tribuna published an interview with former President Daniel Ortega in which he warned the Sandinistas would be obliged to "take up arms" if the government did not cede to the strikers' demands of easing an austerity plan.

"If we let the government continue applying its dictatorial project there will be no alternative but to take up arms once again to end the dictatorship," Ortega, a former guerrilla commander who was president from 1984 to 1990, said.
Local radio reports said protesters had formed "human barricades" on some roads outside Managua, and one police official suffered a cut lip when he was struck by a rock.
Vice Minister of Transportation Pablo Hurtado Vijil said the majority of bus routes were functioning across Nicaragua and police were clearing the roadblocks.
